column1: '''''J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography''''' is a book by [[Humphrey Carpenter]]. Originally published in [[1977]], it is the official, authorized biography of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]].
The authorized biography of the creator of [[Middle-earth]]. In the decades since his death in September [[1973]], millions have read [[The Hobbit
column2: THE HOBBIT]], [[The Lord of the Rings
column3: THE LORD OF THE RINGS]], and [[The Silmarillion
column4: THE SILMARILLION]] and become fascinated about the very private man behind the books.

column1: Born in [[South Africa]] in January [[1892]], John Ronald Reuel Tolkien was orphaned in childhood and brought up in near-poverty. He served in the [[World War I
column2: first World War]], surviving the [[Battle of the Somme]], where he lost many of the closest friends he'd ever had. After the war he returned to the academic life, achieving high repute as a scholar and university teacher, eventually becoming Merton Professor of English at [[University of Oxford
column3: Oxford]] where he was a close friend of [[C.S. Lewis]] and the other writers known as [[Inklings

column1: Then suddenly his life changed dramatically. One day while grading essay papers he found himself writing 'In a hole in the ground there lived a [[Hobbits
column2: hobbit]]' -- and worldwide renown awaited him.

column1: [[Humphrey Carpenter]] was given unrestricted access to all Tolkien's papers, and interviewed his friends and family. From these sources he follows the long and painful process of creation that produced THE LORD OF THE RINGS and THE SILMARILLION and offers a wealth of information about the life and work of the twentieth century's most cherished author.
